clearQueue.label: Clear TTS Queue
clearQueue.tooltip: Clears the text to speech queue in case someone spammed your queue.

minPowerLevel.label: Min Power Level
minPowerLevel.tooltip: Minimum power level required to be able to trigger Text-To-Speech.

userPointsCost.label: Cost to trigger TTS
userPointsCost.tooltip: How many points will be subtracted when a user uses the TTS command.

userCooldown.label: User Cooldown (seconds)
userCooldown.tooltip: How many seconds a user has to wait until he is allowed to use the TTS command again.

userMaxQueues.label: Max Queues per User
userMaxQueues.tooltip:
How many TTS queues a user is allowed to have active.
E.g. if this value is at 5, it means the user has to wait until his first TTS is played until he is allowed to queue another one.

defaultVoice.label: Default Voice
defaultVoice.tooltip:
In case you only selected one language you can use your command with the sentence behind it (e.g. !tts Hello World).
If you select multiple languages you need to add the language key after the command (e.g. !ttsde Hallo Welt or !ttsen Hello World)

userMaxMessageLength.label: TTS Message Length
userMaxMessageLength.tooltip:
How many characters are allowed per TTS message?
Although Twitch messages have a limit of 500 characters, it seems that text-to-speech only works on up to 270 characters.

randomKey.label: Unique Key
randomKey.tooltip:
This acts as a "secret key" to trigger your TTS messages.
If you notice that a TTS goes off that wasn't triggered in your channel, change your key!
It means that someone else is using this key (on purpose or accidently) to trigger messages in your stream.
So make sure your key is unique!

btnGoToOauth.label: TTS Website
btnGoToOauth.tooltip: Opens a tab in your default browser that directs you to your browser source URL and where you can get your unique key from.
